title: 106_hr921
content: The "Swine Producers Market Loss Assistance Act of 1999" includes sections on short title, table of contents, findings and purposes, definitions, market loss assistance, payment amounts, relationship to other payments, emergency requirements, mandatory livestock market reporting, and regulations. Congress finds that recent changes in the marketing relationships of swine producers with meat packers have adversely affected swine prices. The concentration of the meat packing industry and the increase in live swine imports have reduced slaughter capacity and impacted swine prices in the United States. Additionally, a swine market price crisis occurred from October 1, 1998, to December 31, 1998, due to these factors. The swine market price crisis in the United States from October 1, 1998, to December 31, 1998, was influenced by a 10% increase in swine available for slaughter, an 8% decrease in packer slaughter capacity, and a 37% increase in Canadian swine imports. This led to the lowest live swine prices in the United States spot market for the 20th century during the fourth quarter of 1998. During the fourth quarter of 1998, there was a 37 percent increase in Canadian swine imports into the United States. Swine producers experienced a significant reduction in equity capital investment, with the lowest live swine prices in the United States spot market for the 20th century. Additionally, swine producers' share of the consumer pork dollar was approximately $0.22 in 1998, marking the first year they received less than 30 percent of the consumer dollar spent on pork products. In 1998, swine producers received only $0.22 of the consumer pork dollar, marking the first time they received less than 30 percent of the total spent on pork products. Despite stable retail prices, pork consumption increased by seven percent, making it the only meat protein with a net per capita consumption increase over the previous year. The purpose of the Act is to compensate swine producers for losses incurred due to adverse economic factors in the swine market in the fourth quarter of 1998. The Act aims to compensate swine producers for losses in the fourth quarter of 1998 due to adverse economic factors and government failures in pursuing foreign trade opportunities. The Act aims to compensate swine producers for losses in the fourth quarter of 1998 due to adverse economic factors and government failures in pursuing foreign trade opportunities. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "swine" refers to porcine animals raised in the US for feeder pigs or slaughter. "Swine producer" is a person in the US who produced swine during the crisis period from October 1, 1998, to December 31, 1998. "Packer" is defined as per the Packers and Stockyards Act, 1921. "Feeder pig" denotes young swine sold for further feeding for over a month during the crisis period. "Swine operation" refers to individuals or groups raising swine as a single unit. The term "feeder pig" refers to young swine sold for further feeding for over a month during the crisis period. The term "swine operation" denotes individuals or groups raising swine as a single unit in the United States. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Agriculture. SEC. 4. MARKET LOSS ASSISTANCE. The Secretary of Agriculture will provide financial assistance to swine producers to offset market losses incurred during a crisis period. Eligibility requires maintaining a swine operation and marketing swine for slaughter. Certain producers, like those affiliated with publicly owned packers, are ineligible for assistance. The Secretary of Agriculture will provide financial assistance to swine producers during a crisis period. Certain swine producers affiliated with publicly owned packers are ineligible for assistance. The application process involves submitting necessary information for eligibility determination. SEC. 5. PAYMENT AMOUNTS AND PAYMENT LIMITATIONS. Assistance under this Act will be distributed fairly and equitably to swine producers who have incurred losses. Payments to eligible producers will not exceed $25.00 per slaughter-weight swine or $9.00 per feeder pig marketed during the crisis period. Payments to swine operation producers under this Act shall not exceed $9.00 per feeder pig marketed during the crisis period. Payment limitations state that payments may not exceed $50,000 per swine operation for a swine producer. SEC. 6. RELATIONSHIP TO OTHER PAYMENTS. Assistance provided under this Act is in addition to assistance, payments, and loans obtained from other programs such as the Agricultural Market Transition Act, noninsured crop assistance program, crop insurance indemnities, and emergency loans for 1998 production. Payments under the Small Hog Operation Program of the Department of Agriculture, announced on January 8, 1999, will be deducted from payments made to swine producers under this Act. SEC. 7. Emergency Requirement; Use of Commodity Credit Corporation. Congress designates funds as emergency requirement for this Act. The Secretary will utilize Commodity Credit Corporation for Act provisions. SEC. 8. Mandatory Livestock Market Reporting. Amendment to Agricultural Marketing Act for mandatory livestock market reporting. In this section, livestock is defined as cattle, sheep, and swine, whether alive or dead. Livestock product refers to any product derived from livestock, including boxed beef, boxed lamb, and value-added pork products. A packer is defined as a person involved in buying livestock for slaughter, processing livestock products, or marketing unmanufactured livestock products in commerce. The term 'packer' refers to a person involved in buying livestock for slaughter, processing livestock products, or marketing unmanufactured livestock products in commerce. Prices, volume, and terms of sale include various factors such as base price, premium, discount price factors, and quality characteristics. The term 'Secretary' refers to the Secretary of Agriculture. Mandatory reporting is required for packers estimated by the Secretary. The term 'packer' refers to a person involved in buying livestock for slaughter, processing livestock products, or marketing unmanufactured livestock products in commerce. The Secretary requires mandatory reporting for packers estimated to be engaged in buying, manufacturing, preparing, or marketing more than five percent of livestock or livestock products in the United States. The Secretary mandates packers involved in buying, processing, or marketing livestock products in the US to report information on prices, volume, and terms of sale for domestic and imported livestock. Packers must separately report domestic and imported livestock and products. The Secretary requires packers to report domestic and imported livestock and products separately by the next business day. Noncompliance is unlawful, and the Secretary can verify information accuracy and impose penalties if necessary. The Secretary may verify information accuracy and impose penalties on packers for violations of reporting requirements, with a civil penalty of up to $10,000 per violation after providing notice and a hearing. The Secretary may issue a cease and desist order and impose a civil penalty of up to $10,000 per violation on packers for offenses, considering factors like gravity of the offense and business size. If penalties are not appealed or upheld, the case may be referred to the attorney general. The Secretary may refer unpaid civil penalties to the Attorney General for recovery in court if not paid after appeal. Voluntary reporting by packers not under mandatory reporting is encouraged. The Secretary must ensure timely availability of information. The Secretary can recover civil penalties in court if unpaid, and voluntary reporting by packers is encouraged. Information must be made available to the public in a timely manner while protecting the identities of parties and packers involved. The reporting requirement under the Packers and Stockyards Act ensures confidentiality of parties and packers involved in transactions, protects proprietary business information, and expires after three years. This section does not affect the Secretary's authority to collect voluntary reports under other laws. The reporting requirement established by subsection (b) of the Packers and Stockyards Act will expire after three years. Section 416 of the Act, added by the Agriculture Appropriations Act of 1999, is repealed. SEC. 9. REGULATIONS. The Secretary and the Commodity Credit Corporation must issue regulations promptly after the enactment of the Act to implement it. The regulations will address misrepresentations, appeals, and entitlement to benefits without following certain procedural requirements. The regulations for implementing the Act must be issued promptly by the Secretary and the Commodity Credit Corporation. These regulations will address misrepresentations, appeals, and entitlement to benefits without following specific procedural requirements, including notice and comment provisions, the Secretary of Agriculture's Statement of Policy, and the Paperwork Reduction Act. Congressional review of agency rulemaking will be conducted using the authority provided under section 808(2) of title 5, United States Code.
